deck.definition: A type of malware that attaches itself to a host application and must be executed by the user or system.
Self-replicating malware that travels throughout a network without the assistance of host application or user interaction.
Malicious software that appears to be legitimate but contains harmful components, such as installing a backdoor.
A type of malware that gains root-level or kernel-level access and modifies system files or access to hide itself.
Software that records keystrokes and transmits them to a remote location.
A type of malware that takes control of a user's data or system and demands a ransom for release.
Malware that monitors and collects a user's activity and sends the information to a third party.
A type of social engineering attack that uses email to trick users into revealing personal information.
Occurs when an application receives more data than it can handle, potentially causing system crashes or security vulnerabilities.
An attack where an attacker intercepts and possibly alters communication between two parties without their knowledge.
An attack that involves inserting malicious SQL code into input fields to access or manipulate a database.
An attack that involves injecting malicious scripts into web applications to execute them on client-side browsers.
An attack that tricks a user into performing unintended actions on a website.
A process of exploiting a vulnerability to gain higher-level privileges, such as admin or root access.
A type of attack where a malicious actor sends falsified ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) messages over a local network.
An attack that involves corrupting the DNS resolver cache to redirect users to malicious websites.
An attack where an attacker steals a user's session ID to impersonate them on a website or network.
An attack where a malicious actor tricks a user into clicking on something other than what the user intends.
A Virtual Private Network that encrypts traffic and allows secure remote access to a network.
An encryption protocol used to secure internet protocol communications by authenticating and encrypting data.
Protocols that secure communications over a computer network, typically used for web traffic (HTTPS).
A security flaw that is unknown to the software vendor and has no available patch or fix.
A security process in which the user provides two different forms of identification before gaining access.
A method of attack that relies on manipulating people into divulging confidential information.
A system that monitors network traffic for signs of malicious activity.
A system that actively monitors and stops malicious network traffic before it can enter a network.
A set of technologies used to detect and prevent data breaches or unauthorized data transfers.
A set of rules used to control the incoming and outgoing traffic to or from a network resource.
A network segment that acts as a buffer zone between an internal network and the outside world.
A system that aggregates, analyzes, and correlates security data from various sources within an organization's IT infrastructure.
A cloud computing model that provides a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications.
A cloud computing model that provides virtualized computing resources over the internet.
A cloud computing model that delivers software applications over the internet.
A RAID configuration that mirrors data between two drives, ensuring data redundancy in case of drive failure.
A RAID configuration that uses striping for performance and parity for data redundancy, requiring a minimum of three drives.
The process of regularly updating software with patches to address security vulnerabilities and bugs.
A device that distributes incoming network traffic across multiple servers to ensure optimal performance and reliability.
Running an application in a restricted environment to prevent it from affecting the host system.
FDE (Full Disk Encryption) encrypts the entire disk, while SED (Self-Encrypting Drives) provide built-in encryption features for the disk itself.
Vulnerability scanning identifies vulnerabilities but doesn't exploit them, while penetration testing actively exploits vulnerabilities to test security.
A security model that requires verification for every request, regardless of its origin, to ensure that no one, inside or outside, is trusted by default.
